title: How to Sew a Crotch Seam

steps.headline: Lay 2 fabric pants pieces so the right sides face together.
steps.description: Take the front and back pants pieces that you assembled from a pattern and lay 1 flat on your work surface so the right side faces up. Then, stack the other piece directly on the bottom piece so the wrong side faces up.Did You Know? The right side of the fabric has the pattern visible. Once you've stacked the pieces properly, the wrong side should face up.

steps.headline: Pin the pieces together at the center of the inner leg seams.
steps.description: Line up the edges of the fabric pieces and find the middle of the crotch pieces. This is where the fabric curves into a deep U-shape. Take a sewing pin and insert it through both pieces of fabric at the vertical crotch seam.For even more stability, you could use another pin and insert it going from the opposite side of the vertical seam.

steps.headline: Insert sewing pins through the top corner of the inner leg pieces.
steps.description: Ensure that the fabric edges are lined up along the top of the inner leg pieces so the corners are even. Then, insert a sewing pin perpendicularly through both layers of fabric at the inner corners.It's important to insert the pins so they're perpendicular to the curved line of the crotch. This makes it easier to remove the pins as you're sewing.

steps.headline: Push sewing pins along the entire curve of the crotch.
steps.description: Keep checking that the fabric pieces are perfectly lined up and continue to pin the fabric around the inner curve. Use sewing pins about every 2 or 3 inches (5.1 or 7.6 cm) so the fabric doesn't slide around.You'll probably use about a dozen sewing pins to completely pin the crotch in place.

steps.headline: Set your sewing machine to straight stitch.
steps.description: Take your pinned pants pieces over to the sewing machine and thread the machine. Then, adjust your sewing machine to make straight stitches that are about 2.5 millimetres (0.098 in) long.Don't flip the fabric over before you start sewing or you'll have trouble removing the pins as you stitch around the crotch.

steps.headline: Sew along the top corner of the crotch.
steps.description: Leave a ⁄8 inch (1.6 cm) seam allowance as you stitch down towards the rounded curve of the crotch. Remove sewing pins as you stitch so you don't damage your machine.Tip: If you're sewing pants that have an elastic waistband, follow your pattern's instructions about sewing along the top corner of the leg pieces. You may need to leave a small gap for inserting the elastic later. Avoid sewing the crotch seam by hand, especially if you're using heavy fabric. The machine makes strong, tight stitches that will hold up better over time.

steps.headline: Stitch around and up to the straight sides of the crotch.
steps.description: Keep straight stitching with a ⁄8 inch (1.6 cm) seam allowance until you reach the inner corner that's opposite to the one you started at. Guide the fabric to create a straight seam.Hold the inner leg seam open as you sew across it at the bottom of the crotch curve.

steps.headline: Line the center of the presser foot with the stitch line.
steps.description: Slide the fabric so the presser foot is just above the line of stitches where they begin to curve down into the crotch. Position the fabric until the center of the pressure foot lines up with the line of stitches that you already made. Then, lower the presser foot.You don't have to reinforce the vertical sides of the crotch since it doesn't get as much wear and tear as the curved area of the crotch.

steps.headline: Stitch over the curved bottom of the crotch to reinforce the stitches.
steps.description: Make another row of straight stitches directly of the first row of stitches you made. This creates strong, reinforced stitches that prevent the crotch from splitting.Did You Know? There's no need to backstitch when you start or finish the reinforced row because you're stitching onto the previous row. The existing stitches act as knots that stop the new row of stitches from coming undone.

steps.headline: Trim the excess fabric in the curve of the crotch.
steps.description: Once you've reinforced the stitches, take a sharp pair of scissors and carefully cut away the fabric of your seam allowance. Only trim the curved bottom part of the crotch where you reinforced the stitches.Do not cut into the stitches or your thread will unravel.
